content.text: In the Netherlands, when ordering water at a restaurant, bottled water is usually served rather than tap water.

content.title: Using 'mag ik...'
content.explanation: The expression 'mag ik...' means 'may I have...?'. It's a polite way to ask for something.

content.title: Order at the restaurant!
content.setting: You are at a restaurant in Amsterdam. The LLM will act as the waiter.
content.user_goal: Politely order bread and water using the phrases you have learned.
content.llm_persona: Act as a friendly Dutch waiter. Respond in Dutch in a simple and natural way. Your goal is to help the user practice. If the user has difficulties, subtly guide them to use the expression 'Mag ik...'. Keep your responses short.
content.initial_prompt: Goedenavond! Wat kan ik voor u doen?
content.success_condition: The user has correctly ordered water and bread using the structure 'Mag ik...'.

content.text: In Dutch, 'oo' is pronounced as a long 'o', similar to 'oo' in 'boot'.

content.title: Exclamations with 'wat...'
content.explanation: The word 'wat' can be used to make exclamations: 'Wat mooi!' (How beautiful!), 'Wat lekker!' (How tasty!).

content.title: Enjoy the park
content.setting: You are walking in a Dutch park and see trees, dogs, and bicycles.
content.user_goal: Point out things you see and use 'Wat mooi!' when appropriate.
content.llm_persona: Act as a friendly Dutch local walking their dog. Respond with short, encouraging Dutch sentences.
content.initial_prompt: Hallo! Mooie dag in het park, toch?
content.success_condition: The user describes at least one thing they see and uses 'Wat mooi!'.

content.title: Using 'waar is...'
content.explanation: The phrase 'waar is...' means 'where is...'. You can use it to ask where something is located.

content.text: Dutch supermarkets often have a large dairy section with many kinds of cheese.

content.title: Find the groceries
content.setting: You are in a Dutch supermarket looking for milk and cheese.
content.user_goal: Ask where items are and thank the staff.
content.llm_persona: Act as a helpful supermarket employee, answering politely in Dutch.
content.success_condition: The user successfully asks where the milk and cheese are and thanks the employee.

content.title: Using 'naar...'
content.explanation: The preposition 'naar' means 'to'. You use it with destinations, e.g. 'naar Utrecht' (to Utrecht).

content.text: Dutch trains are often punctual. Always check the platform ('perron') before boarding.

content.title: Buy a train ticket
content.setting: You are at a train station in the Netherlands.
content.user_goal: Ask for a ticket to Utrecht and find out the price.
content.llm_persona: Act as a ticket clerk at the station, answering politely in Dutch.
content.success_condition: The user correctly asks for a ticket to Utrecht and asks how much it costs.

content.title: Introducing yourself
content.explanation: The phrase 'ik heet...' means 'my name is...'. You can introduce yourself this way in Dutch.

content.text: When greeting in the Netherlands, a handshake is common in formal situations. Among friends, three cheek kisses are traditional.

content.title: Meet someone new
content.setting: You meet someone for the first time at a social event.
content.user_goal: Greet them, ask how they are, and introduce yourself.
content.llm_persona: Act as a friendly Dutch person meeting someone new. Respond with short, natural Dutch sentences.
content.success_condition: The user greets, asks how the other person is, and introduces themselves.
